snippet: A growing homeless population on public lands has brought with it increases in emergency calls, drug overdoses, illegal fires and trash, which have put nearby residents on edge....
abstract: Thousands of homeless and dislocated people, as last resort, are living off grid in America's national forests; Forest Service officers in charge of public lands are dealing with more emergency calls, drug overdoses, illegal fires and trash, and tensions between homeless and many residents of towns that lie on edges of forests has reached boiling point.
lead_paragraph: A growing homeless population on public lands has brought with it increases in emergency calls, drug overdoses, illegal fires and trash, which have put nearby residents on edge.

headline.main: As Homeless Find Refuge in Forests, ‘Anger Is Palpable’ in Nearby Towns
headline.print_headline: Tensions Soar as Drifters Call National Forests Home
